text: For prototype 1: How much would you trust this tool to give accurate information?
For prototype 1: What features, if any, made you trust or distrust the interface?
answers: It would help to see the evidence (perhaps a link) that disproves the misleading claim in the yellow highlight.
who is responsible for flagging false or misleading statements? Is there any threshold for community notes or can anyone submit one? This lack of transparency makes me doubt the accuracy
There isn't much context as to how the assessment is made. Upon what information are you basing the statement that the claim is misleading? And how are the community notes aggregated, exactly?
distrust - it does not say source of evaluation. trust - additional feedback
The author name and institution name made me trust it
The presence of additional information related to claims
The way of phrasing the sentences seem reliable to me
It does not look professionally maintained
Why would  I trust this source
I can't see any links to evidence or sources. It just feels like it could be equally biased.

text: For prototype 1: Which feature(s) did you find most useful?
answers: I like that certain words are highlighted
the highlights directly in the article
I like that the assessment happens contextually without having to increase the user's cognitive load
Show the note on the same page, so the user does not need to jump back and forth

text: For prototype 1: Which feature(s) did you find unnecessary or confusing?
answers: It would be nice to be able to hover over the words to see the comment
I don't know how the article accuracy is calculated
As stated before, unclear how the mechanic activates and how the assessment is determined.
the exclamation point at the top right
Hard to gauge what is actually verifying the claims (or what a verifiable claim even is).
